    • startGame

      public void startGame​(javafx.stage.Stage stage)

    • loadSpriteImages

      private void loadSpriteImages()
      Preload sprite images and return references to their Image objects. This prevents us from continually loading new images as the sprite layer refreshes, which is especially bad if javafx doesn't release them.

    • update

      public void update​(java.util.Observable observable, java.lang.Object o)

      Parameters:

      o - Arbitrary data

      Create and assemble the game UI.

    • renderCity

      private void renderCity​(City city)
      Render a single city to the map.
      Parameters:
      city - The city to render. Position will be derived from the City's stored coords

    • renderUnit

      private void renderUnit​(Unit unit)
      Render a single unit to the map.
      Parameters:
      unit - The unit to render. Position will be derived from the Unit's stored coords

    • renderSpriteHPBar

      private void renderSpriteHPBar​(double cur, double max, int x, int y)
      Place an inline HP bar above a certain map square
      Parameters:
      cur - The unit or city's current hp
      max - The unit or city's max hp
      x - The left iso coord of the space to render on
      y - The top iso coord of the space to render on

    • clearAllSprites

      private void clearAllSprites()
      Clear all currently rendered sprites.

    • renderFog

      private void renderFog()
      Render fog of war on top of the map and sprites based on what the current player has already discovered.

    • updatePlayers

      private void updatePlayers()
      Render an overlay with readouts of all current players. These readouts act as a key, mapping players to colors that are then reflected on units and cities, and also provide some quick data about each player's remaining units and cities.

    • cssClassFrom

      private java.lang.String cssClassFrom​(java.lang.String str)
      Normalize a string into a form more suitable for a css class by lowercasing it and replacing spaces with dashes
      Parameters:
      str - The string to classname-ify
      Returns:
      A suitable css classname

    • focusMap

      private void focusMap​(int x, int y, boolean animate)
      Center the map on a particular board index.
      Parameters:
      x - The x index of the board grid to center on
      y - The y index of the board grid to center on
      animate - True if this refocus should be smooth/animated, false if it should be instant

    • focusFirstPlayerUnit

      private void focusFirstPlayerUnit​(Player player, boolean useFallback)
      Given a player, focus on a unit or city associated with that player. This doesn't guarantee focus on any particular unit, only the first found. Prefers units over cities.
      Parameters:
      player - The player to focus on
      useFallback - If true, focus on the center of the map if no units or cities could be found. If false, don't refocus the map if no units or cities could be found

    • handleMapClick

      private void handleMapClick​(javafx.scene.input.MouseEvent ev)
      Handle an arbitrary click on the map at any time.
      Parameters:
      ev - The event object generated from the click

    • handleMapHover

      private void handleMapHover​(javafx.scene.input.MouseEvent ev)
      Give visual indication of hover within the map.
      Parameters:
      ev - The MouseEvent generated by a hover on the canvas

    • deselect

      private void deselect()
      Deselect the currently selected unit and/or city. Also hides the respective detail pane(s)

    • selectUnit

      private void selectUnit​(Unit unit)
      Select a unit. This involves marking said unit as selected, centering the map on it, and building and showing a detail pane that displays the unit's properties.
      Parameters:
      unit - The Unit to select

    • selectCity

      private void selectCity​(City city)
      Select a city. This involves marking said city as selected, centering the map on it, and building and showing a detail pane that displays the city's properties.
      Parameters:
      city - The City to select

    • selectTile

      private void selectTile​(int x, int y)
      Add a selection indicator to a tile and center the view on it.
      Parameters:
      x - The x index of the tile in the map grid
      y - The y index of the tile in the map grid

    • addRangeIndicators

      private void addRangeIndicators​(Unit unit)
      Add an indicator to each tile that a given unit can currently move to and/or attack.
      Parameters:
      unit - The unit to indicate valid moves for

    • addOwnershipIndicators

      private void addOwnershipIndicators​(City city)
      Add an indicator to each tile under a given city's ownership/influence
      Parameters:
      city - The city to add indicators for

    • createLabeledFigure

      private javafx.scene.text.TextFlow createLabeledFigure​(java.lang.String label, int figure, int max, java.lang.String disposition)
      Assemble a TextFlow with a common layout for figures and their associated labels.
      Parameters:
      label - The label text to render
      figure - The primary figure value
      max - If the figure has a max value, pass it here. Otherwise, pass a negative number
      disposition - The disposition class to render ("positive", "neutral", or "negative") or an empty string if not applicable
      Returns:
      The assembled TextFlow object containing the data inside new Text nodes

    • createHPBar

      private javafx.scene.layout.GridPane createHPBar​(double cur, double max)
      Create a standardized structure representing an HP bar.
      Parameters:
      cur - The current HP
      max - The max HP
      Returns:
      A structure of Nodes that represent an HP bar

    • createCityBuildButton

      private javafx.scene.Node[] createCityBuildButton​(City city, java.lang.String label, double pointCost, javafx.scene.image.Image resource)
      Create and assemble the nodes necessary to display a 'build' button with associated costs, for display on a city detail pane.

      Styles the button and labels depending on whether enough resources exist to build the unit.

      Parameters:
      city - The city this would build to
      label - The label to add to the button
      pointCost - The production point cost that building this unit requires
      Returns:
      A two-element node array. The first element is the containing GridPane for the entire row so it can be added to the layout. The second element is the created Button so the calling method can attach an event listener to it

    • getDrawTraversal

      private java.util.List<int[]> getDrawTraversal()
      Get a serialized list of board coordinates in diagonal-traversal order starting from the top-left of the board.

      This is necessary because the board must be drawn back-to-front in order for perspective overlapping to appear correct.

      Returns:
      A list of two-element int arrays, where the first int is the board x index and the second is the board y index

    • gridToIso

      private int[] gridToIso​(int x, int y)
      Given a set of grid space coordinates, return the pixel coordinates of the tile in our isometric rendering space.

      The coordinates returned indicate the top-left bound of the iso space. Use in combination with this class' TILE_SIZE and ISO_FACTOR constants to do additional math afterwards (like finding the center point of the space, etc).

      Parameters:
      x - The x index of the space in the map grid to find
      y - The y index of the space in the map grid to find
      Returns:
      A two-element int array containing the x and y coordinates of the top-left pixel of the input tile in iso space

    • isoToGrid

      private int[] isoToGrid​(double x, double y)
      Translate absolute pixel coordinates in the isometric display to grid spaces.

      Note that returned indices may be outside the real bounds of the grid due to the natural negative space that any isometric view has in the corners. Since this method doesn't necessarily return "safe" indices, make sure to check.

      Parameters:
      x - The horizontal pixel offset of the coordinate from the left edge of the canvas
      y - The vertical pixel offset of the coordinate from the top edge of the canvas
      Returns:
      A two-element int array containing the x and y indices of the space in the grid

    • getTileImage

      private javafx.scene.image.Image getTileImage​(Tile.terrainTypes terrainType)
      Get a tile image for a terrain type.

      Since there can be many tile choices for a given terrain type, this method chooses one randomly. Don't expect the same image for the same terrain type each time.

      Parameters:
      terrainType - The terrain type to get a file for
      Returns:
      An Image object containing the image data for a tile image matching the terrain type

    • getRandInt

      private int getRandInt​(int min, int max)
      Generate a random integer in a given range.
      Parameters:
      min - The minimum possible result (inclusive)
      max - The maximum possible result (inclusive)
      Returns:
      A random integer between the two bounds, inclusive

    • buildMenu

      private void buildMenu​(javafx.stage.Stage stage)
      buildMenu() builds our Main Menu for our game. This menu includes a New Game, Load Game and Exit button
      Parameters:
      stage - our primary stage for our javafx environment
      stage - our stage for our javafx environment

    • newGameMapSelection

      private void newGameMapSelection​(javafx.stage.Stage stage)
      newGameMapSelection builds the menu for map selection when the user selects New Game from the Main Menu. This includes .png previews of our Maps, a button for each map and a text element informing the User how many players each Map supports. It also includes a "return to menu" button that will redraw our Main Menu.
      Parameters:
      stage - our primary stage for our javafx environment

    • attemptLoadGame

      private void attemptLoadGame​(javafx.stage.Stage stage)
      attemptLoadGame() is called when the User clicks the "Load Game" button on our Main Menu. If it cannot load a game, it displays an Alert indicating that no saved game was found and allows the user to select a different option. If it can load a game, it loads the game and starts it.
      Parameters:
      stage - our primary stage for our javafx environment

    • queryMapSize

      private void queryMapSize​(javafx.stage.Stage stage)
      queryMapSize draws a Menu screen with four menu options. Map4 is variably sized and can be one of the four options that the user wants: 20x20, 30x30, 40x40, 50x50. This Menu includes buttons for all four of these options and, upon clicking, sets the View's mapSize field. This menu also includes a "Return to Menu" button that redraws our Main Menu when clicked.
      Parameters:
      stage - our primary stage for our javafx environment

    • queryPlayerCount4

      private void queryPlayerCount4​(javafx.stage.Stage stage)
      queryPlayerCount4() builds a menu for the User to select how many players they'd like in their game. Map1 and Map4 support 1-4 human players, so this menu contains four options and will set the view's numPlayers field when clicked. Also contains our Return to Menu Button
      Parameters:
      stage - our primary stage for our javafx environment

    • queryPlayerCount3

      private void queryPlayerCount3​(javafx.stage.Stage stage)
      queryPlayerCount3() builds a menu for the User to select how many players they'd like in their game. Map2 supports 1-3 human players, so this menu contains three options and will set the view's numPlayers field when clicked. Also contains our Return to Menu Button
      Parameters:
      stage - our primary stage for our javafx environment

    • queryPlayerCount2

      private void queryPlayerCount2​(javafx.stage.Stage stage)
      queryPlayerCount2() builds a menu for the User to select how many players they'd like in their game. Map3 supports 1-2 human players, so this menu contains two options and will set the view's numPlayers field when clicked. Also contains our Return to Menu Button
      Parameters:
      stage - our primary stage for our javafx environment
